awd_titl_txt: CPATH-2: Collaborative Research: A Field Guide to the Science of Computation
awd_abstract_narration:
This CPATH award supports a distinguished group of computer scientists to develop, implement, and test a Field Guide for computing. The Field Guide includes a body of content with deep insights to provide a scientific framework for computing.  The content is then tested by a collaborative partnership network including the ACM Education Board, the Computer Science Teachers Association, CS Unplugged, and LabRats. Implementation will occur in a wide variety of settings, including the BASIS Middle School and High School in Tuscon, one of the top high schools in the United States, and the Hartnell College, a 2 year college in California. The project includes a large team of experts broken into 4 working groups and distinguished scientific advisors. An external evaluator will measure the effectiveness of the content and field guide to attain the project goals.

This project's long-range objective is to replace current views of computing with a new understanding, that computing is great domain of science, on par with the physical, life, and social sciences. This project directly supports the three main CPATH goals. (1) It contributes to US competitiveness by providing a scientific framework for computing, which will advance technology development and attract many more bright students, including more women and underrepresented groups. (2) It increases the number of students developing computational thinking by offering new learning possibilities, for undergraduates as well as for pre-college students. (3) It is transformative because it brings forward a science framework for computing, which has not been done before.

Intellectual Merit. The project brings to the fore an underappreciated side of
Computing, that it is a great domain of science based on sound scientific theories and first principles. The ambitious project has amassed a stellar team of experts and organizational partners that span broad sectors of computing and the computing pipeline. It includes not only development of content, but deployment in real settings, and concrete plans for sustainability.  Computation science offer deep insights and surprising predictions, and an experimental method to validate predictions and make discoveries. This project has the potential to substantially impact the fundamental nature of computing and its relationship to other disciplines and the way in which computing is taught.

Broader Impacts. By reaching out from hard-core computer science to representatives of different age groups, the project will find ways to convey the science message to many generations. It will also provide solid grounding for other scientists to interact with computer scientists as peers in the search for new discoveries.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: RET SUPP-Res Exp for Tchr Supp
REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
Many scientists, engineers, and students see computing as a technology field but not a field of science or engineering. This project’s long-range
objective is to replace this with a new understanding, that computing is great domain of science, on par with the physical, life, and social sciences.

The main objective in the University of Arizona portion of this project is to produce online labs that will enable students in middle school and above to become involved with the science of computing by conducting experiments. The idea is that by emphasizing the scientific perspective within computer science through these labs, we can interest more students that already are interested in traditional sciences (biology, chemistry, physics) to also consider computer science. Our three lines of investigation are: (1) identify and evaluate scientific theories within computing, (2) develop online web laboratorie, and (3) test and integrate labs into real courses.

We have identified seven such theories: Cognitive Load Theory (in the area of computer human interaction), Fitt's Law (originated in ergonometrics, but is applicable to computer human interaction), Locality Theory (originated in the area of operating systems, but much more broadly applicable), Manhattan Theory (in the area of image processing), Phase Transition Theory (in the area of algorithms), Queueing Theory (in the area of computer and software systems performance analysis), and Social Network Theory (in the area of web science).

We have also developed the LoCuS (Laboratory for Computer Science) infrastructure. This system is substantial, at abut 50,000 source lines of code. The system provides an interactive lab notebook that guides students and records their observations and analyses. This environment includes over a dozen apparatuses that allow students to run experiments and collect data, data sets that students can study and manipulate. We have tested these labs in experiments over the last few years in middle school, high school, and introductory college classes, to over 400 students. These students have performed a total of about 3000 online labs. Through the development of online labs at different levels and through beta testing them with middle school, high school, and introductory college students, we are learning the characteristics uch labs must exhibit to be engaging to such students.

This new understanding will make the field more attractive for students and science collaborators. We are now doing controlled studies to determine the extent to which these labs change perceptions of computer science.

This Project Outcomes Report for the General Public is displayed verbatim as submitted by the Principal Investigator (PI) for this award. Any opinions, findings, and conclusions or recommendations expressed in this Report are those of the PI and do not necessarily reflect the views of the National Science Foundation; NSF has not approved or endorsed its content.


Last Modified: 01/07/2014
Modified by: Richard T Snodgrass

We have identified seven such theories: Cognitive Load Theory  (in the area of computer human interaction), Fitt's Law (originated in  ergonometrics, but is applicable to computer human interaction), Locality Theory (originated  in the area of operating systems, but much more broadly applicable),  Manhattan Theory (in the area of image processing), Phase Transition  Theory (in the area of algorithms), Queueing Theory (in the area of computer and software  systems performance analysis), and Social Network Theory (in the area  of web science).
